page.title: 15Leisure around Framfield
page.content: During the summer months many of the gardens in the area are opened to the public.Entrance fees are donated to a named charity such as nurses' homes. On June 16th, 1985, six gardens could be visited for Â£1 in aid of Conservative Party funds. Pembroke Manor joined in this scheme. It specialises in wildfowl and ornamental pheasants although wild mink living in the nearby stream constantly deplete the stocks.Now one house, Pembroke manor was originally three cottages for farm workers at New Place Farm. The house and garden are maintained by a family of four living in a nearby converted stable block. In exchange for their labour,for which they are paid, they have full access to the leisure facilities in the grounds. These include a swimming pool, tennis court, croquet lawn and billiard room.
